q: What is an ectopic pregnancy?
a: An ectopic pregnancy is when a fertilised egg implants itself outside of the womb, usually in one of the fallopian tubes.

q: What are the symptoms of an ectopic pregnancy?
a: Symptoms of an ectopic pregnancy can include a missed period, tummy pain low down on one side, vaginal bleeding or brown watery discharge, pain in the tip of the shoulder, and discomfort when peeing or pooing.

q: When should I seek medical advice for an ectopic pregnancy?
a: You should contact your GP or call NHS 111 if you experience a combination of symptoms such as tummy pain, vaginal bleeding, missed period, or shoulder pain and you might be pregnant.

q: When should I get emergency help for an ectopic pregnancy?
a: You should call 999 or go to your nearest accident and emergency department immediately if you experience sharp, sudden and intense pain in your tummy, feeling very dizzy, fainting, or looking very pale.

q: What are the treatments for an ectopic pregnancy?
a: There are three main treatments for an ectopic pregnancy: expectant management, medicine with methotrexate injection, and surgery with keyhole surgery (laparoscopy). The choice of treatment depends on various factors and will be recommended by your doctor.

q: How can I get support after an ectopic pregnancy?
a: If you need support after an ectopic pregnancy, you can speak to your GP about professional support or counselling. There are also support groups such as The Ectopic Pregnancy Trust, Ectopic Pregnancy Foundation, Miscarriage Association, and Cruse Bereavement Care.

q: When can I try for another baby after an ectopic pregnancy?
a: It is usually recommended to wait until you've had at least 2 periods after treatment before trying for another baby. If you were treated with methotrexate, it's usually recommended to wait at least 3 months.

q: What can cause an ectopic pregnancy?
a: The causes of an ectopic pregnancy are not always clear, but factors such as problems with the fallopian tubes, pelvic inflammatory disease, previous ectopic pregnancy, previous surgery on the fallopian tubes, fertility treatment, becoming pregnant with an intrauterine device (IUD) or intrauterine system (IUS), smoking, and increasing age can increase the risk.

q: How can I reduce the risk of an ectopic pregnancy?
a: To reduce the risk of an ectopic pregnancy, you can use a condom when not trying for a baby to protect against STIs, and stop smoking if you smoke.

q: Is it possible to prevent an ectopic pregnancy?
a: You can't always prevent an ectopic pregnancy, but you can reduce the risk by taking precautions such as using contraception, protecting against STIs, and maintaining a healthy lifestyle.

q: What is an ectopic pregnancy?
a: An ectopic pregnancy is when a fertilised egg implants itself outside of the womb, usually in one of the fallopian tubes.

q: How common is ectopic pregnancy in the UK?
a: In the UK, around 1 in every 90 pregnancies is ectopic, which is approximately 11,000 pregnancies a year.

q: What are the symptoms of an ectopic pregnancy?
a: Symptoms can include a combination of a missed period, tummy pain low down on one side, vaginal bleeding or a brown watery discharge, pain in the tip of your shoulder, and discomfort when peeing or pooing.

q: When should I seek medical advice for a possible ectopic pregnancy?
a: You should contact your GP or call NHS 111 if you have a combination of symptoms and you might be pregnant, even if you haven't had a positive pregnancy test.

q: When should I seek emergency help for a possible ectopic pregnancy?
a: You should call 999 or go to your nearest accident and emergency (A&E) department immediately if you experience a sharp, sudden and intense pain in your tummy, feel very dizzy or faint, or look very pale.

q: What treatments are available for an ectopic pregnancy?
a: There are three main treatments for an ectopic pregnancy: expectant management, medicine, and surgery.

q: What support is available after an ectopic pregnancy?
a: If you or your partner are struggling to come to terms with the loss of the pregnancy, you may benefit from professional support or counselling. Support groups such as The Ectopic Pregnancy Trust, Ectopic Pregnancy Foundation, Miscarriage Association, and Cruse Bereavement Care can also provide help.

q: When can I try for another baby after having an ectopic pregnancy?
a: You will likely be advised to wait until you've had at least 2 periods after treatment before attempting to conceive again. If you were treated with methotrexate, it's usually recommended that you wait at least 3 months.

q: What can increase the risk of ectopic pregnancy?
a: Factors such as pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), previous ectopic pregnancy, previous surgery on the fallopian tubes, fertility treatment like IVF, becoming pregnant while using an IUD or IUS, smoking, and increasing age are associated with an increased risk of ectopic pregnancy.

q: How can the risk of ectopic pregnancy be reduced?
a: The risk of ectopic pregnancy can be reduced by using a condom when not trying for a baby to protect against STIs, and by quitting smoking if you smoke.
